title: 100 followers problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The length of one side of a triangle is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\left(\\sqrt{3}+1\\right)\\text{ cm}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" The two interior angles on that side are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30^\\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"45^\\circ."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the area of the triangle?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the triangle be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle ABC=30^\circ "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle ACB=45^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AD"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the altitude drawn to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} \tan 45^\circ & =1\Rightarrow AD=DC \\ \tan 30^\circ & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow \frac{AD}{\sqrt{3}+1-AD}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \sqrt{3}+1-AD & =\sqrt{3} AD \\ AD=1 \\ \text{area}(\triangle ABC) & =\frac{1}{2}\cdot 1 \cdot (\sqrt{3}+1) \\ & = \boxed{1.6602} \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            Nice way Bhaiya but there may have been other possibilities like if the side "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sqrt{3}+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is opposite to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"30^{o}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then the area may change?

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The ~ angle ~  opposite ~  of ~  side ~  ~  \sqrt3+1  ~  ~ is ~  180-30-45=105. \\
\therefore  ~ side ~  opposite ~  \angle  ~ 30, ~  say ~  x ~  ~ ,=(\sqrt3+1)*\dfrac{Sin30}{Sin105}.\\
Area=\frac 1 2*\{\sqrt3+1\}*x*Sin45=\frac 1 2*\dfrac{(\sqrt3+1)^2}{Sin105}*Sin30*Sin45=1.366 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"my solution is a bit longer, but it too yields the correct answer.
What i did was that using the sine law (or whatever it is called)
i marked all the angles. 30, 45, 105.
sin of an angle /its opposite side =sin of the other angle/its respective opposite side.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {\sin 105}{\sqrt{3} + 1}= \frac {\sin 30}{x}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
so
 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x = \sqrt{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
side opposite to 30 degree angle is 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" sqrt{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
similarly side opposite to 45 is 2.
now i dropped an altitude to the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sqrt {3} +1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  side. this becomes an isosceles triangle.
so two arms containing the right angle become 1 because their hypotenuse is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" sqrt{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
so i calculated the areas of these two new triangles which turned out to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0.866025437844386567636 +0.5 = 1.366025437844386567636 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In∆ABC /"},{"type":"text","text":"B=45° and /","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"C=30°. Also BC=√3+1.
By sine rule,
BC sinC=AB sinA.          [/_A=105°]
=> AB=√2.
Similarly we get,AC=2.  [sin105°=(√3+1)/2√2]
Now,area=1/2×(sinA×AB×AC)
                 =(√3+1)/2
                =1.366"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100+ followers problem 1
100 followers problem-1
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large1^{100}+2^{100}+3^{100}+\\ldots+100^{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the last two digits of the above expression."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X=\sum_{n=1}^{100} n^{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We need to find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X (\text{mod }100)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which amounts to finding "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X (\text{mod }4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X (\text{mod }25)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Euler-Fermat tells us that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^2\equiv 1 (\text{mod }4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" coprime to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", hence so is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not coprime to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (i.e. even), then certainly "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{100}\equiv 0 (\text{mod }4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X\equiv 50\cdot 0+50\cdot 1\equiv 50 (\text{mod }4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Likewise, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{20}\equiv 1 (\text{mod }25)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" coprime to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"25"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", hence so is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" giving us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X\equiv 80\cdot 1+20\cdot 0\equiv 80 (\text{mod }25)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Combining this gives us, thanks to the Chinese remainder theorem, the unique solution "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X\equiv 30 (\text{mod }25)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X\equiv 30 (\text{mod }4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X\equiv \boxed{30} (\text{mod }100)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We note that for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i,j = 0,1,2,...9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(10i+j)^{100} \equiv j^{100} \pmod {100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^{100} {k^{100}} & \equiv 10 \sum _{k=1} ^{10} {k^{100}} \pmod{100} \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=1,3,7,9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are coprimes of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then Euler's totient theorem applies:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow a^{\phi{(10)}} & \equiv 1 \pmod{10} \\ a^{4} & \equiv 1 \pmod{10} \\ \Rightarrow a^{100} & \equiv a^{4\times 25} \equiv 1 \pmod{10} \\ 5^{100} & \equiv 5 \pmod{10} \\ 2^{100} & \equiv 2^{5\times 5 \times 4} \equiv 32^{5 \times 4} \equiv 2^{5 \times 4} \equiv 2^{4} \equiv 6 \pmod{10} \\ 4^{100} & \equiv 2^{100\times 2} \equiv 6 \pmod{10} \\ 6^{100} & \equiv 2^{100}3^{100} \equiv 6 \pmod{10} \\ 8^{100} & \equiv 2^{100\times 3} \equiv 6 \pmod{10} \\ 10^{100} & \equiv 0 \pmod{10}  \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \sum_{k=1}^{100} {k^{100}} & \equiv 10 \sum _{k=1} ^{10} {k^{100}} \pmod{100} \\ & \equiv 10 (1+6+1+6+5+6+1+6+1 +0) \pmod{10} \\ & \equiv  330 \pmod{10} \\ & \equiv  \boxed{30} \pmod{10}  \end{aligned}  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 followers Problem

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider the following"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} 4\cos (e^x) & = 2^x + 2^{-x} = e^{x\ln 2} + e^{-x\ln 2} & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{Divide both sides by }4
\\ \cos (e^x) & = \frac {e^{x\ln 2} + e^{-x\ln 2}}4 & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{Let }u = e^x
\\ \cos u & = \frac 14 \left(u^{\ln 2} + u^{-\ln 2}\right) & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{where }u \in (0, \infty)
\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e^x > 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the domain of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0, \infty)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We note that the LHS "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\cos u \in [-1, 1]"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". From AM-GM inequality, the RHS has a minimum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac 12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u^{\ln 2} + u^{-\ln 2} \ge 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and equality occurs when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore, the RHS "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\in [\frac 12, \infty)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and it is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\le 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where the solutions exist, when "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \frac 14 \left(u^{\ln 2} + u^{-\ln 2}\right) & \le 1
\\ u^{\ln 2} + u^{-\ln 2} & \le 4
\\ u^{2\ln 2} - 4 u^{\ln 2} + 1 \le 0
\\ \left(u^{\ln 2} - 2 - \sqrt 3\right) \left(u^{\ln 2} - 2 + \sqrt 3\right) & \le 0
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies 0.1496 \le u \le 6.6859"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when the RHS is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\le 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Since the range of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6.6859-0.1496 = 6.5363 > 2\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed 4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" solutions as confirmed by the graph below (LHS = blue line, RHS = red line). "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/fvQvzBrxmh-b180921.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 followers problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\large \\prod _{ n=1 }^{ \\infty  }{ \\left( 1+\\frac { 1 }{ \\left\\lfloor \\sqrt [ 100 ]{ n }  \\right\\rfloor  }  \\right)  }^{(-1)^{n-1}} =\\frac { \\pi  }{ a } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" that satisfies the above equation."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large \displaystyle \prod _{ n=1 }^{ \infty }{ \left( 1+\frac { 1 }{ \left\lfloor \sqrt [ 100 ]{ n } \right\rfloor } \right) }^{(-1)^{n-1}} =\frac { \pi }{ a } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Taking logs on both sides of this equation  shows us that 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
\ln{\frac{\pi}{a}} = \displaystyle \sum_{ n=1 }^{ \infty }{ (-1)^{ n-1 } \ln{\left( 1+\frac{1}{ \left\lfloor \sqrt [ 100 ]{ n } \right\rfloor } \right) }} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Upon expanding this sum, we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \ln{\frac{ \pi }{ a }} \space = \space \ln{2} - \ln{\frac{3}{2}} + \ln{\frac{4}{3}} - \cdots "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \implies \ln{\frac{\pi}{a}} \ = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}{ (-1)^{n-1} \ln{\frac{n+1}{n}} } \ = \ \ln{ \left( 2 \times \frac{2}{3} \times \frac{4}{3} \times \cdots \right) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The product contained in the logarithm above is the Wallis' product, which evaluates to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\pi}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\ln{\dfrac{\pi}{a}} \ = \ \ln{\dfrac{\pi}{2}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \ = \ 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 followers problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large 4(a^6+b^6+c^6)+5abc(a^3+b^3+c^3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are reals satisfying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab+bc+ca=\sqrt[3]{100}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the minimum value of the expression above."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Source: Israel winter camp 2015 test."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Symmetric expressions always attain minimum values when its variables are all equal."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus for the minimum value we can take "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b=c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" giving us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a^2=100^⅓"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the minimum value of the expression as "},{"type":"text","text":"100","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
